The depression in freezing point can be calculated as:

$$\Delta T_f = \frac{nRT_{\text{melt}}^2}{\Delta H_{\text{melt}}}$$

$$n$$ is the amount of substance (in mol) of ions in 1 dm^3 of solution:
$$n = (3 \text{ mol dm}^{-3}) \times (1 \text{ dm}^3) = 3 \text{ mol}$$

$$R$$ is the gas constant:
$$R = 8.314 \text{ J mol}^{-1} \text{ K}^{-1}$$

$$T_{\text{melt}}$$ is the melting point of pure water:
$$T_{\text{melt}} = 273 \text{ K}$$

$$\Delta H_{\text{melt}}$$ is the standard enthalpy change of melting for pure water:
$$\Delta H_{\text{melt}} = 6.01 \text{ kJ mol}^{-1}$$

Substituting these values into the equation, we get:

$$\Delta T_f = \frac{(3 \text{ mol})(8.314 \text{ J mol}^{-1} \text{ K}^{-1})(273 \text{ K})^2}{6.01 \times 10^3 \text{ J mol}^{-1}} = -1.86 \text{ K}$$

Therefore, the freezing point of a 3 mol dm^{-3} solution of sodium chloride is:

$$273 \text{ K} - 1.86 \text{ K} = \boxed{271.1 \text{ K}}$$

$$2H_2(g) + O_2(g) \rightarrow 2H_2O(l)$$

$$\Delta H_f^°(CH_4) = -74.8 \text{ kJ mol}^{-1}$$

$$\Delta H_f^°(H_2O) = -285.8 \text{ kJ mol}^{-1}$$

$$\Delta H_c^°(H_2) = ?$$

The standard enthalpy change of combustion is related to the standard enthalpy of formation by the following equation:

$$\Delta H_c^° = -2\Delta H_f^°(H_2O)$$

Substituting the values into the equation, we get:

$$\Delta H_c^° = -2(-285.8 \text{ kJ mol}^{-1}) = \boxed{571.6 \text{ kJ mol}^{-1}}$$

The depression in freezing point can be calculated as:

$$\Delta T_f= \frac{rac{{nRT_{melt}}^2}}{\Delta H_{melt}}$$

$$n$$ is the amount of substance (in mol) of ions in 1 dm^3 of solution:
$$n=3\text{ mol dm}^{-3}\times2=6\times10^{-3}\text{ mol}$$

$$T_f$$ is the melting point of pure water: 273 K

$$\Delta H_{melt}$$ is the standard enthalpy change of melting for pure water: 6.01 kJ mol^{-1}

$$R$$ is the gas constant: 8.314 J mol^{-1} K^{-1}$$

$$\Delta T_f= \frac{(6\times10^{-3}\text{ mol})(8.314\text{ J mol}^{-1} K^{-1})(273\text{ K})^2}{6.01\times10^3\text{ J mol}^{-1}}= -1.8\text{ K}$$

Therefore, the freezing point of a 3 mol dm^{-3} solution of calcium chloride is:

$$273\text{ K}-1.8\text{ K}=\boxed{271.2\text{ K}}$$
